title: 108_hr1647
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Crane Conservation Act of 2003". Congress acknowledges the serious decline of crane populations globally, particularly in Africa, Asia, and Europe. Five species of Asian cranes are listed as endangered under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 and the Convention. The Crane Action Plan identifies four African crane species and one Asian species as seriously threatened. The wattled crane, blue crane, grey-crowned crane, black-crowned crane, and sarus crane are seriously threatened. The whooping crane and Mississippi sandhill crane are endangered with low population numbers. Conservation efforts have not been enough to address the decline in crane populations due to hunting and habitat loss. Conservation resources have not been sufficient to cope with the continued diminution of crane populations from hunting and habitat loss. Cranes are flagship species for wetland, grassland, and agricultural conservation. Other threats include egg collection, poisoning, collisions with power lines, disturbance from warfare, and trapping for sale. Joint commitment is needed to address these threats effectively. Cranes face threats such as hunting, habitat loss, egg collection, poisoning, power line collisions, warfare disturbance, and trapping for sale. Joint commitment from countries and the private sector is necessary to address these threats. Cranes are important ambassadors for promoting goodwill among countries due to their migration across continents. Conservation efforts and successes in one region can be applied to other regions where cranes are found. Conservationists in the United States can learn from and collaborate with colleagues in other countries to conserve threatened crane populations. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of cranes, support conservation programs in countries where endangered cranes occur, assist private organizations dedicated to crane conservation, and provide financial resources for these efforts. The term "conservation" in this Act refers to methods and procedures to ensure the population of crane species in the wild is sufficient to prevent extinction, including habitat protection, research, management plans, enforcement, and community involvement. The Act focuses on the development of management plans for crane ranges, enforcement of the Convention, law enforcement and habitat protection through community participation, reintroduction of cranes to the wild, conflict resolution initiatives, and community outreach and education. The terms "Convention," "Fund," and "Secretary" are defined within the Act. SEC. 5. CRANE CONSERVATION ASSISTANCE. The Secretary will use funds from the Fund to provide financial assistance for crane conservation projects approved by the Secretary. Applicants must submit project proposals meeting specific requirements, and eligible applicants include relevant wildlife management authorities in certain regions. The Secretary will use funds from the Fund to provide financial assistance for crane conservation projects approved by the Secretary. Eligible applicants include wildlife management authorities in specific regions, the Secretariat of the Convention, and experts in crane conservation. Project proposals must include a concise purpose statement, details of project personnel and their qualifications, and methods for project implementation. The project proposal must include a description of project personnel qualifications, methods for project implementation, staff and community management, logistics, estimated funds and time required, government support, matching funding details, and any other necessary information for evaluation. The Secretary reviews project proposals within 30 days of receipt and consults with relevant Federal officials. Within 180 days, the Secretary consults with the governments of countries involved before approving or disapproving the proposal. The Secretary, after consulting with relevant Federal officials, consults with the governments of countries involved, approves or disapproves project proposals, and notifies the applicant and other officials. Projects are approved if they enhance conservation programs for cranes and address conflicts between humans and cranes. The Secretary approves project proposals that enhance conservation programs for cranes and address conflicts between humans and cranes by assisting in implementing conservation programs, addressing habitat conflicts, enhancing compliance with laws, developing scientific information on crane habitat and populations, and promoting cooperative projects among various entities. The Secretary approves project proposals that promote cooperative projects among governmental entities, local communities, NGOs, and private sector, conduct necessary scientific research on cranes, reintroduce cranes into the wild, and provide training to enhance conservation capacity. Preference is given to projects ensuring long-term conservation and those with matching funds available. The Secretary gives preference to projects that focus on long-term conservation of cranes and habitats or have matching funds available. Recipients of assistance must submit reports to evaluate project progress and success, which will be made available to the public. The Secretary convenes a panel of experts biennially to identify conservation needs for cranes. The Secretary convenes a panel of experts biennially to identify conservation needs for cranes, including the establishment of a Crane Conservation Fund. Establishment of the Crane Conservation Fund within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund, with provisions for funding and expenditures for crane conservation efforts. The Secretary determines necessary amounts for assistance under section 5, with a limit of 3% or $80,000 for administrative expenses. Not more than 50% of the Fund can be used for North American crane conservation projects. The Treasury Secretary invests excess Fund amounts in interest-bearing US obligations. The United States can acquire obligations for investments in the Fund either on original issue at the issue price or by purchasing outstanding obligations at the market price. Any obligations acquired by the Fund can be sold at the market price. Interest and proceeds from the sale or redemption of obligations held in the Fund are credited to the Fund. Amounts required to be transferred to the Fund are done so monthly from the Treasury's general fund based on estimates by the Treasury Secretary, with adjustments made for any prior overestimations or underestimations. The Secretary of the Treasury makes estimates for transferring amounts to the Fund, with adjustments for any prior overestimations or underestimations. Donations can be accepted and used for assistance, with the amounts transferred to the Treasury for deposit in the Fund. SEC. 7. ADVISORY GROUP.

To assist in carrying out this Act, the Secretary may convene an advisory group consisting of individuals representing public and private organizations actively involved in the conservation of cranes. The advisory group shall ensure that each meeting is open to the public, provide an opportunity for interested persons to present statements, and keep minutes available to the public.

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$3,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated to the Fund for each fiscal year from 2004 through 2007, remaining available until expended.
